channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syria’s Shaky Peace Talks Move Toward Solid Ground in Effort to Aid Homs
item.description: The Syrian government and opposition met face to face in Geneva for the first time to try to win government approval for an aid convoy to parts of Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Not All Egyptians Cheer Uprising’s 3rd Anniversary
item.description: Some Egyptians commemorated their revolt against autocracy by holding a giant rally for the military leader who ousted the country’s first democratically elected president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Government Dossier Accusing U.S. in Carnage Amplifies Doubts About Karzai
item.description: The government of President Hamid Karzai handed out an inflammatory dossier about airstrikes on Jan. 15 on a remote village and the supposed American cover-up that followed.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: An image of a funeral in Afghanistan that the government tied to a recent American airstrike actually took place in 2009.

item.title: The Lede: Scarlett Johansson’s SodaStream Endorsement Deal Conflicts With Charity Work, Aid Group Says
item.description: Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its global ambassadors, Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli firm that makes products in a settlement in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: China Accuses Uighur Intellectual of Separatism for His Advocacy Work
item.description: A statement from security officials in the Xinjiang region accused Ilham Tohti, an economics professor who advocates on behalf of Uighurs, of separatism and inciting ethnic hatred.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Ukrainian President Offers Top Posts to Opposition Leaders
item.description: Immediate indications were that a proposal for reshaping the government by President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not being well received on the street.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: DealBook: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
item.description: Syria, the Iraq war and other trouble spots were hot-button issues in a panel that included Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona, and Aleksei K. Pushkov, the head of Russia’s parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Senator John McCain at a session on Friday at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: DealBook: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
item.description: With China’s rise and the Federal Reserve’s economic action both in retreat, investors have been heading for the exits in markets as far removed as Buenos Aires, Istanbul and Beijing, with effects spilling over into the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange on Friday, where the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index ended its worst week since June 2012.

item.title: Clashes in China’s Restive Region Kill 12
item.description: Chinese state media say six people have died in explosions and another six were shot dead by police in fresh violence in the far west region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Filmmaker Who Mocks Authorities on YouTube Detained Amid Widening Crackdown in Cairo
item.description: The sense that Egypt’s revolution has come full circle intensified with the arrest of an artist who posts wry commentaries on the country’s leaders on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Erosion of Argentine Peso Sends a Shudder Through Latin America
item.description: The decline in Argentina’s currency is the steepest since the country’s economic collapse in 2002, and it is raising fears of a global slump in developing countries.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT, SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing: U.S. Catholics Hope for 2015 Papal Visit
item.description: A spokesman for the archdiocese of Philadelphia said he expects Pope Francis to attend an event there in September 2015, although the Vatican has not given official word.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistani Court Sentences Briton to Death for Blasphemy
item.description: Mohammed Asghar, a mentally ill British man, was arrested in 2010 for claiming to be the Prophet Muhammad in letters that were later produced at his trial.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Olympic Fears Rattle Athletes and Families
item.description: With the Sochi Olympics only weeks away, American athletes and their families are increasingly concerned about the security preparations in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: A Russian police officer searching a driver as his vehicle was screened at an entrance to the site of the Winter Olympics.

item.title: World Briefing: Cold and Ice in Quebec Hamper Search in Fire’s Ruins
item.description: Using steam to melt the ice, investigators searched the frozen-over ruins of a retirement home in Canada on Friday for victims of a fire.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gaza Man Shot to Death in Border Clash With Israeli Military, Palestinians Say
item.description: It was the latest in a series of violent exchanges that have frayed a fragile 14-month-old cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A brother of Bilal Auwaida wept at his funeral on Friday in Beit Lahiya in northern Gaza. Mr. Auwaida, 20, was killed on Friday in a clash with Israeli soldiers near the border fence.

item.title: Star Envoy’s Frankness Puts Kennedy Mystique to Test in Japan
item.description: Japan swooned when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador, but she has surprised her hosts with her frankness on delicate issues, including a controversial dolphin hunt.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Caroline Kennedy took the traditional carriage ride to meet Emperor Akihito in Tokyo last year.

item.title: Kerry Presses Iranians to Prove Nuclear Work Is for Peaceful Purposes
item.description: John Kerry told the World Economic Forum that Iran must accept extensive verification of its nuclear program, abandon plans for a plutonium-producing reactor, and resolve inspectors’ concerns about past compliance.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday that “an era of American diplomatic engagement” is following a decade defined by force.

item.title: Listening Post: Iran’s Message at Davos Has Eerie Echo
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani’s speech this week, professing peaceful intentions and a desire for dialogue, invited comparisons to Mohammad Khatami’s attempt at change 10 years ago.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Prolonged Fight Feared in Egypt After Bombings
item.description: Four deadly bombings left a grim realization that a cycle of terrorism and repression is hardening the wills of the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency to fight to the death.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: South Sudanese Rebels Accuse Government of Ignoring Day-Old Cease-Fire
item.description: A government spokesman denies the claims that opposition positions were attacked, while analysts say that enforcing the cease-fire will prove more difficult than signing it.
item.dc:creator: By BENNO MUCHLER

item.title: Kiev Truce Falls Apart, and Unrest Resurges
item.description: Protests have spread to cities across the nation, even as a cease-fire disintegrated in the Ukrainian capital.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Orthodox priests pray as they stand between protesters and the police in Kiev early Friday.

item.title: New Commissioner Has Ties to ‘Sherlock,’ via Barbados
item.description: Stacey Cumberbatch, appointed as New York’s commissioner of citywide administrative services, shares some history with the British actor Benedict Cumberbatch.
item.dc:creator: By KATE TAYLOR
item.media:description: Stacey Cumberbatch was appointed New York's commissioner of citywide administrative services on Friday.

item.title: 2 Sides in Syria Peace Talks Agree to Meet in the Same Room, Averting a Breakdown
item.description: The sides were expected to spend much of Saturday trying to agree on a cease-fire to allow aid to reach areas blockaded by the government in Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian opposition coalition arriving for a meeting with the United Nations special envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, in Geneva, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Writer Tells Africa What He Couldn’t Tell ‘Mum’
item.description: The Kenyan author Binyavanga Wainaina’s decision to come out as gay had added to the fierce debate over homosexuality in sub-Saharan Africa.
item.category: One Day I Will Write About This Place (Book)
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Sven Torfinn for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kenyan writer Binyavanga Wainaina is one of the most prominent Africans to come out as gay.
